title: What is leukemia? - Danilo Allegra and Dania Puggioni

multiple-choice.question: Which type of cancer is most commonly diagnosed in children?
What is a key characteristic of a stem cell?

options.label: A
options.text: Limited potential for growth and development

options.label: B
options.text: Ability to perform a single function in the body

options.label: C
options.text: Ability to differentiate into various cell types

options.label: D
options.text: Specialization into a single cell type

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of platelets in the blood?

options.label: A
options.text: Carrying oxygen from the lungs to tissues

options.label: C
options.text: Helping to stop bleeding by sticking to damaged blood vessels

multiple-choice.question: What is a contributing factor to the high incidence of leukemia in children?

options.label: C
options.text: The occurrence of just one or two DNA modifications

multiple-choice.question: Why is chemotherapy used to treat leukemia?

options.label: B
options.text: To destroy rapidly multiplying leukemic cells

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential side effect of chemotherapy for leukemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased production of red blood cells

options.label: C
options.text: Damage to healthy cells, such as those found in hair follicles or intestines

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of a bone marrow transplant in treating leukemia?

options.label: C
options.text: To restore normal bone marrow function and blood cell production

multiple-choice.question: Why is antigen compatibility important in bone marrow transplantation?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent rejection of the transplanted cells and ensure a successful graft

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the risk of infection

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the risk of cancer

multiple-choice.question: What is required for a successful bone marrow transplant?

options.label: C
options.text: Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) compatibility between the donor and recipient

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of having a large database of bone marrow donors?

options.label: C
options.text: Improving the chances of finding a compatible donor for patients in need

title: Why neutrinos matter - Sílvia Bravo Gallart

multiple-choice.question: What are neutrinos, and how do they interact with matter?

options.label: A
options.text: Neutrinos are composite particles that interact strongly with matter.

options.label: B
options.text: Neutrinos are elementary particles that cannot be subdivided and hardly ever interact with anything.

options.label: C
options.text: Neutrinos are a type of radiation that can travel through solid objects and interact with matter frequently.

options.label: D
options.text: Neutrinos are atoms that can be broken down into smaller particles and interact with matter strongly.

multiple-choice.question: Where are neutrinos produced in the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: Only in nuclear reactors and particle accelerators.

options.label: B
options.text: Only in the Earth's atmosphere and inside the Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: In a variety of locations, including the human body, the Earth's atmosphere, inside the Earth, the sun, and in nuclear reactors and particle accelerators.

options.label: D
options.text: Only in supermassive black holes and cosmic dynamos.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the IceCube neutrino telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect cosmic rays and their interactions with matter.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the properties of neutrinos and their interactions with matter in a laboratory setting.

options.label: C
options.text: To observe high-energy cosmic neutrinos and learn about their origins.

options.label: D
options.text: To generate high-energy neutrinos in nuclear reactors and particle accelerators.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists detect neutrinos at the IceCube neutrino telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: By using photomultiplier tubes alone to amplify the signal of charged particles.

options.label: B
options.text: By using boreholes to drill into the ice and detect neutrinos directly.

options.label: C
options.text: By using only a huge volume of pure transparent material to detect neutrinos that collide with the nucleus of an atom.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of a huge volume of pure transparent material and photomultiplier tubes to detect neutrinos that collide with the nucleus of an atom.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the photonic boom produced by high-energy neutrino collisions?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a sign of the neutrino's presence, but it doesn't provide any information about the neutrino's properties.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a sign of the neutrino's presence and contains information about the charged particles' paths and energies.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a sign of the neutrino's absence, and it indicates that the neutrino has interacted with matter.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a sign of the neutrino's presence, but it only provides information about the neutrino's energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the world's largest neutrino telescope?
How many detectors are located in the IceCube neutrino telescope?
What is the process by which high-energy neutrinos are thought to be accelerated to extreme energies in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Cosmic ray acceleration by supermassive black holes or cosmic dynamos.

options.label: C
options.text: Particle acceleration by magnetic fields in the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: Supermassive black hole acceleration of charged particles in the Earth's atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the discovery of the highest energy cosmic neutrinos ever seen by the IceCube neutrino telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: It indicates that neutrinos are not produced in the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: It indicates that neutrinos are not accelerated to extreme energies in space.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides evidence for the existence of supermassive black holes and other cosmic engines that can accelerate cosmic rays to extreme energies.

options.label: D
options.text: It provides evidence for the existence of dark matter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the age of astronomy that we are currently entering, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: The age of cosmic ray astronomy

options.label: D
options.text: The age of dark matter astronomy

title: Could your brain repair itself? - Ralitsa Petrova

multiple-choice.question: What potential reality are scientists investigating regarding the brain's ability to repair itself?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability of the brain to compensate for damaged areas by reorganizing existing cells

options.label: B
options.text: The possibility of the brain rebooting and updating its cells with new, improved units

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of the brain to adapt to new environments through neuroplasticity

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of the brain to learn new information through synaptic strengthening

multiple-choice.question: What process involves the production of new cells in the adult brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Neuroplasticity, the brain's ability to reorganize and adapt

options.label: B
options.text: Neurogenesis, the growth and development of new neurons

options.label: C
options.text: Synaptogenesis, the formation of new synapses between neurons

options.label: D
options.text: Myelination, the process of insulating neural fibers

multiple-choice.question: In which three specialized locations has neurogenesis been discovered in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The hippocampus, the cerebellum, and the frontal lobe

options.label: B
options.text: The dentate gyrus, the subventricular zone, and the striatum

options.label: C
options.text: The temporal lobe, the parietal lobe, and the occipital lobe

options.label: D
options.text: The limbic system, the basal ganglia, and the brainstem

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of neural stem cells and progenitor cells in the process of neurogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce new neurons and replace old or damaged ones

options.label: B
options.text: To break down old neurons and recycle their components for energy

options.label: C
options.text: To produce neurotransmitters and regulate brain function and behavior

options.label: D
options.text: To support the growth and development of other brain cells, such as astrocytes

multiple-choice.question: What are two promising approaches being investigated to repair damaged brain tissue?

options.label: A
options.text: Administering certain proteins and small molecules to stimulate neural stem cells

options.label: B
options.text: Transplanting healthy human neural stem cells into injured tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Using gene therapy to repair damaged brain cells and restore function

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of teaching other kinds of brain cells to behave like neural stem cells?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce more neurons and improve brain function and cognition

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce inflammation and promote healing in damaged brain tissue

options.label: C
options.text: To improve the efficiency of neural stem cells in producing new neurons

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the number of neural stem cells available for repair

multiple-choice.question: What is a major goal of regenerative medicine in relation to brain repair?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for neurological disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease

options.label: B
options.text: To improve the efficiency of neural stem cells in producing new neurons

options.label: C
options.text: To enable the brain to self-repair and regenerate damaged tissue

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the mechanisms of neurogenesis and its role in brain function

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many neurons are estimated to be in the human brain?
What happens to newly generated neurons in the developing brain?

options.label: A
options.text: They are eliminated through a process called apoptosis, or programmed cell death

options.label: B
options.text: They migrate to different parts of the developing brain to form distinct structures

options.label: C
options.text: They remain in the same location where they were generated and differentiate

options.label: D
options.text: They differentiate into other types of brain cells, such as astrocytes or oligodendrocytes

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential outcome of research on neurogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of new treatments for neurological disorders, such as Parkinson's disease

options.label: B
options.text: The improvement of brain function and cognitive abilities through neuroplasticity

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of new mechanisms of brain development and function

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of the brain to self-repair and regenerate damaged tissue

title: How to unboil an egg - Eleanor Nelsen

multiple-choice.question: What type of energy can reverse the effects of thermal energy on egg molecules?
According to the principle of microscopic reversibility, what can theoretically happen to egg proteins that have seized up?

options.label: C
options.text: They can theoretically return to their original state if you retrace your steps

options.label: D
options.text: They can only form new bonds with each other

multiple-choice.question: What chemical acts as a lubricant when dissolving boiled egg whites in water to help proteins glide past each other?
Why do scientists spin the solution of dissolved egg whites at a high speed of 5000 rotations per minute?

options.label: A
options.text: To create sheer stresses that repeatedly stretch and contract the proteins

options.label: C
options.text: To separate the proteins by size

multiple-choice.question: What laboratory technique is used to unboil egg whites by spinning them at high speeds?
What is a key application of the unboiling technique in the pharmaceutical industry?

options.label: D
options.text: To untangle and refold proteins that get stuck in aggregates

multiple-choice.question: What chemical reaction makes chemical changes to sugars and proteins during cooking, making them harder to "uncook"?
How does boiling an egg differ from other types of cooking?

options.label: A
options.text: Boiling an egg changes the chemical identity of proteins

options.label: B
options.text: Boiling an egg doesn't change the chemical identity of proteins

options.label: C
options.text: Boiling an egg is the only type of cooking that uses heat

options.label: D
options.text: Boiling an egg is the only type of cooking that changes protein shapes

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of the unboiling technique in the pharmaceutical industry?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a more expensive method than other ways to refold proteins

options.label: B
options.text: It is a quicker and cheaper method than other ways to refold proteins

options.label: C
options.text: It is a more complicated method than other ways to refold proteins

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on protein production costs

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what type of food cannot be "unfryed" yet due to the chemical changes that occur during cooking?

options.label: D
options.text: Any food that undergoes the Maillard reaction

title: How to spot a counterfeit bill - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of counterfeit bills in the U.S. for every 10,000 legitimate bills?
Why does the iodine solution in the anti-counterfeit detection pen not react with authentic U.S. bills?

options.label: B
options.text: They are printed with invisible ink

options.label: C
options.text: They are made of materials (cotton and linen) that do not contain starch

options.label: D
options.text: They are treated with a special chemical that prevents iodine reaction

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the company that has been producing the material used in authentic U.S. bills since the Revolutionary War?
What is the composition of the amylose molecule found in starch, which is commonly used in counterfeit bills?

options.label: A
options.text: A short chain of sugar molecules connected by carbon atoms

options.label: B
options.text: A long chain of sugar molecules connected by oxygen atoms

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the iodine solution reacting with the amylose molecule in counterfeit bills?

options.label: A
options.text: A light yellow mark on the paper

options.label: B
options.text: A dark mark on the paper

options.label: D
options.text: A change in color of the ink

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the UV light strip on U.S. bills printed since 1996?

options.label: A
options.text: To reveal the presence of starch

options.label: B
options.text: To detect the presence of amylose

options.label: C
options.text: To provide an additional counterfeit countermeasure

multiple-choice.question: Why does the UV light strip on U.S. bills glow under UV light?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it contains molecules that can be excited by UV light

options.label: B
options.text: Because it contains molecules that can be heated by UV light

options.label: C
options.text: Because it contains molecules that can be cooled by UV light

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the excited molecules in the UV light strip return to their original state?
Why does the UV light strip glow at a longer wavelength?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has the same energy

multiple-choice.question: What visual cues should you look for when examining a U.S. bill to determine if it is counterfeit?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the portrait should be lifelike and not flat

options.label: B
options.text: Only the seal should have perfectly even sawtooth points

options.label: C
options.text: Only the inked border should be unbroken

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above (portrait, seal, inked border, and serial number with equal spacing)

title: What's the difference between accuracy and precision? - Matt Anticole

multiple-choice.question: What is the key distinction between accuracy and precision?

options.label: A
options.text: Accuracy refers to the consistency of results, while precision refers to the closeness to the correct result.

options.label: B
options.text: Precision refers to the consistency of results, while accuracy refers to the closeness to the correct result.

options.label: C
options.text: Accuracy and precision are interchangeable terms that refer to the same concept.

options.label: D
options.text: Accuracy refers to the reliability of an instrument, while precision refers to its calibration.

multiple-choice.question: Which term describes how close a result is to the correct value?
What is an example of a situation where precision is high but accuracy is low?

options.label: A
options.text: A factory producing inconsistent products with varying levels of quality.

options.label: B
options.text: A person shooting a target with consistent but inaccurate results, like William Tell with the stolen crossbow.

options.label: C
options.text: A researcher using an uncalibrated instrument to collect data.

options.label: D
options.text: A person navigating with an accurate map but inconsistent compass readings.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a situation where accuracy is high but precision is low?

options.label: A
options.text: A person shooting a target with accurate but inconsistent results, like William Tell with a shaky hand.

options.label: B
options.text: A researcher using an accurate instrument but getting inconsistent results due to human error.

options.label: C
options.text: A factory producing consistent but inaccurate products.

options.label: D
options.text: A doctor prescribing an ineffective medication with a precise dosage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the NASA spacecraft that landed on Mars in 2012 with a significantly reduced landing ellipse?
What was the size of the landing ellipse for the Mars Viking Lander in 1976?
What is the primary advantage of using precise instruments in scientific research?

options.label: D
options.text: They provide results with a high degree of certainty and reduced uncertainty.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Martian crater targeted by the Curiosity Lander in 2012?
What is a challenge in using computer simulations to predict the landing site of a spacecraft on Mars?

options.label: A
options.text: They are inaccurate due to faulty programming.

options.label: B
options.text: They are inconsistent due to hardware malfunctions.

options.label: C
options.text: They require extensive calculations and involve variables with uncertain values.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not account for the Martian atmosphere's density changes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal in scientific research regarding accuracy and precision?

options.label: A
options.text: To prioritize accuracy over precision in all situations.

options.label: B
options.text: To prioritize precision over accuracy in all situations.

options.label: C
options.text: To achieve both high accuracy and high precision, thereby reducing uncertainty.

options.label: D
options.text: To disregard accuracy and precision in favor of other factors.

title: Why are manhole covers round? - Marc Chamberland

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why most manhole covers are round?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide better structural support for the surrounding pavement.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a constant width, preventing them from falling into the hole in any orientation.

options.label: C
options.text: They are easy to roll and slide into place in any alignment, but this is not the primary reason.

options.label: D
options.text: They are designed to withstand heavy loads and stresses.

multiple-choice.question: What geometric property distinguishes a circle from a square?
What shape, other than a circle, is an example of a curve of constant width?
What is the name of the theorem that states the perimeter of any curve of constant width equals pi times the diameter?
According to a mathematical theorem, what characteristic do curves of constant width with the same width share?

options.label: A
options.text: They have different perimeters and areas.

options.label: B
options.text: They have the same perimeter but different areas.

options.label: C
options.text: They have the same area but different perimeters.

options.label: D
options.text: They have the same perimeter and area.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the three-dimensional surface of constant width formed by taking a tetrahedron and expanding spheres from each vertex?
What type of polygon can be used to generate a curve of constant width using the same method as the Reuleaux triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: Any polygon with an odd number of sides.

options.label: B
options.text: Any polygon with an even number of sides.

options.label: C
options.text: Any shape with an odd number of vertices.

options.label: D
options.text: Any regular polygon with an even number of sides.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of rolling a curve of constant width around another curve of constant width?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a curve of variable width.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a curve with a different constant width.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a third curve of constant width.

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a curve with a constant area.

multiple-choice.question: Among curves of constant width with the same width, which one has the largest area?

options.label: C
options.text: Reuleaux polygon with a finite number of sides.

multiple-choice.question: Among curves of constant width with the same width, which one has the smallest area?

options.label: C
options.text: Reuleaux polygon with a finite number of sides.

title: The science of static electricity - Anuradha Bhagwat

multiple-choice.question: What are the three types of smaller particles that make up an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: Positively charged protons, negatively charged neutrons, and neutral electrons

options.label: B
options.text: Negatively charged electrons, positively charged protons, and neutral neutrons

options.label: C
options.text: Positively charged protons, neutral neutrons, and positively charged electrons

options.label: D
options.text: Negatively charged electrons, neutral electrons, and positively charged protons

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of static electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: A balance of charges between two objects

options.label: B
options.text: The transfer of electrons between two objects due to friction or rubbing

options.label: C
options.text: A charge imbalance, or net charge separation, between two objects

options.label: D
options.text: The movement of protons between two objects

multiple-choice.question: Which type of material is more likely to experience static electricity?

options.label: B
options.text: An insulator like plastic or rubber

multiple-choice.question: What can cause the movement of electrons between two objects?

options.label: B
options.text: Friction or rubbing between the objects

options.label: C
options.text: Only a balance of charges between the two objects

options.label: D
options.text: Only the presence of a conductor

multiple-choice.question: Is friction between two objects necessary for static electricity to occur?

options.label: B
options.text: No, friction is not always necessary, but it can contribute to static electricity

options.label: C
options.text: Friction is necessary for static electricity to occur in conductors

options.label: D
options.text: Friction is necessary for static electricity to occur in insulators

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a positively charged object interacts with a negatively charged object?

options.label: A
options.text: The positively charged object repels the negatively charged object

options.label: B
options.text: The positively charged object attracts the negatively charged object

options.label: C
options.text: The positively charged object has no effect on the negatively charged object

options.label: D
options.text: The negatively charged object repels the positively charged object

multiple-choice.question: Which type of door handle is more likely to experience a static discharge when touched by a person who has walked across a carpet?
What is the term for the quick movement of electrons that occurs when a charged object comes into contact with another material?
Where does lightning, a type of static electricity, typically occur?

options.label: B
options.text: On the surface of the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: Between clouds and the ground or within clouds

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of static electricity in terms of its charge?

options.label: C
options.text: Can be either positive or negative

title: What causes bad breath? - Mel Rosenberg

multiple-choice.question: What is the "ancient curse" that has plagued humanity since ancient times, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of mucus, food remnants, and dead tissue cells

options.label: B
options.text: To break down organic matter only

options.label: C
options.text: To aid in digestion and disease prevention

options.label: C
options.text: Using antibacterial mouthwash at bedtime only

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too distracted or busy

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too accustomed to the smell inside their own mouths

options.text: Because they are not paying attention to their oral hygiene

options.text: Cupping your hands over your mouth

options.label: C

title: How we think complex cells evolved - Adam Jacobson

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the process where one organism lives inside another, resulting in a mutually beneficial relationship and the potential for the host organism to gain new abilities?

What drove the evolution of complex cells through the process of one organism absorbing another and taking on its abilities?

options.label: D
options.text: Adaptation to Environmental Conditions through Endosymbiosis

options.label: A
options.text: The blob cells became more complex but did not gain new abilities

options.label: B
options.text: The bacteria were destroyed by the blob cells

options.label: C
options.text: The blob cells gained the ability to move faster

options.label: A
options.text: Chloroplasts and Mitochondria multiply like ancient bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: Chloroplasts and Mitochondria have their own DNA and ribosomes

options.label: C
options.text: The membranes of Chloroplasts and Mitochondria have the same lipids and proteins as ancient bacteria

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the engulfed cell's membrane during the process of endosymbiosis?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes part of the host cell's membrane and is lost

options.label: B
options.text: It is destroyed by the host cell

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes the outer membrane of the organelle

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of new prokaryotic cells

options.label: D
options.text: The combination of powerful abilities to become better adapted to life on Earth

options.label: A
options.text: Museums only accessible by the upper and middle classes

options.label: B
options.text: Museums only open on certain days

options.label: D
options.text: Museums open to the general public

options.label: B
options.text: Determining the frequency of exhibit changes

options.label: D

title: Why are some people left-handed? - Daniel M. Abrams

options.label: A
options.text: If both parents are right-handed, the child is more likely to be left-handed

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: If one parent is left-handed, the child has a 50% chance of being left-handed

options.label: D
